Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Social Upheaval and Religious Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a workshop that will convene an international group of social scientists to consider the relationship between social upheaval and religious innovation. In human societies, periods of great social upheaval, whether due to war, economic change or natural disaster, tend to be accompanied by religious innovation. In such circumstances, people may feel compelled to change religious practices, institutions, or even create new religions. But while it is clear that social upheaval and religious innovation are causally related, much less is known about the nature of these linkages. For example, do social upheavals give rise to religious innovations, is the reverse more often true, or do the causal arrows fly in both directions? The global diversity of both the nature of the upheavals and the religions involved make such questions hard to answer systematically. Therefore, to better understand the relationship between social upheaval and religious change, this workshop has chosen a unique approach. It will focus on a single site where a recent social upheaval has been experienced by all but there are multiple innovating religions operating in the post-upheaval period.

The site is the South Asian country of Sri Lanka, a multi-ethnic, religiously plural state, where Buddhism, Hinduism, Islam, Christianity, and many new religious movements co-exist. In 2009, Sri Lanka concluded a highly disruptive, twenty-six year long, inter-ethnic civil war, costing tens of thousands of lives. The social scientists participating in this workshop comprise specialists in the full gamut of Sri Lanka's traditional religions and new religious movements. The aims of this workshop are three: empirical, theoretical, and practical. Empirically, the workshop will document and compare religious innovation across Sri Lanka in the post-war period, searching for common underlying patterns. The presence or absence of such patterns would set distinct theoretical directions for further work. Practically, the workshop aims use these findings to create a set of common research questions to coordinate future, collaborative research, to leverage the research opportunity presented by having multiple religions present in a single post-war setting. The proceedings of the workshop will be taped for use by other scholars and students. Findings will be disseminated through scholarly publication and public presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop on innovative religiosity in postwar Sri Lanka took place on July 11, 12, and 13, 2017 at the campus of the Open University as planned. Eighteen scholars presented papers over two days; the final day was devoted to discussing implications of the work presented and prospects for publishing the workshop and continuing this research. Of the 19 scholars originally scheduled to appear at the conference 18 delivered papers.

In addition, the workshop was able to bring 29 undergraduate and graduate students to the workshop in Colombo from four Sri Lankan university campuses: the Open University of Sri Lanka, the University of Jaffna, Southeastern University and Eastern University).

The workshop emphasis on "innovative religiosity", or religious innovations occurring at the boundaries of formally acceptable practice, was designed to allow a comparative observational horizon that would include all of Sri Lanka's officially recognized religions (Buddhism, Hinduism, Christianity and Islam), as well as a number of its most prominent "New religious Movements". International and local scholars of Sri Lanka's various religious practices were selected with this in mind. Since changes in religiosity occurring at the boundaries of acceptable practice often address questions of group belonging and exclusion, a further goal of the workshop was to discuss, where possible, changes in relations between Sri Lanka's religious and ethnic groups insofar as these might be reflected in the various innovations workshop scholars were reporting. This, in turn, allowed the workshop to address the more fundamental question of the relationship between innovative religious practices, multi-religious interactions, multi-religious sites, and the engendering of conflict and/or tolerance in a post-conflict society.

Finally, two further practical goals of this project were: 1) to model international scholarly debate for Sri Lankan graduate students and undergraduates by allowing them to actively participate in workshop debates; and 2) to establish an ongoing working group on innovative religiosity in Sri Lanka.

Workshop discussions led to the following conclusions. 1) As the presentations clearly showed, the new prominence of religious innovation since the end of the war is a complex and contradictory phenomenon. 2) It is most apparent at sites of multi-religious activity such as, in Sri Lanka, Kataragama (the site of an annual multi-religious festival), Our Lady of Madhu Shrine (a Marian Catholic Church) and Sri Pada/Adams Peak, all places where devotees of various religions interact. 3) However, at sites prominent before the war, innovative religiosity is often related to pressure from official state Buddhism to crowd out the activities of other religions; as a consequence, there is actually a move toward greater homogeneity at such sites. 4). At the same time, however, new sites of inter-religious interaction are being constructed; and, outside such sites of particular state vigilance, religious innovations are apparent that continue to challenge religious boundaries. 5) The workshop participants were convinced that these results were more apparent because of the broader analytic framework utilized by the workshop.

The workshop has resulted in an international working group on this topic. The group is pursuing publishing revised versions of this workshop's presentations, and continues, as a working group, to discuss this topic over email. By August 2017, 17 of the original workshop attendees agreed to revise their papers for inclusion in a planned scholarly collection. The PI returned to Sri Lanka in July 2018 to help several contributors complete their revised workshop papers and to finalize plans with two co-editors, Dr. Darini Rajasingham-Senanayake and S. Pathmanesan, to edit the resulting volume. Our plan is to produce a book with the collection of papers presented at the workshop, updated to reflect current circumstances in Sri Lanka. The PI has been invited to present the results of this workshop, and the research it gave rise to, in February and March 2019 at the University of Essex and the University of Bristol in the United Kingdom, and at Maynooth University in Ireland. A paper on this material will also be presented in April at the 2019 conference of the British Association for South Asian Studies at Durham in the United Kingdom. Other participants in the workshop and the resulting working group are also presenting papers at national and international conferences.
